justification: The text describes the rubber hand illusion as a paradigm in which participants experience illusory ownership of a fake hand, and notes that Bayesian models of body ownership have been "captured" using this illusion.

The article states that loss of attenuation of self-generated sensations "has been demonstrated in the force-matching task (Shergill et al., 2005)", linking the task directly to measurement of sensory attenuation.
It reports that cortical EEG recordings show "a suppression of the primary and secondary complexes of the SSEP during active and passive movement," using SSEP amplitude as the index of attenuation.

The review notes that evidence for noradrenergic signalling of volatility is "evidenced by modelling of pupillometric data during online manipulation of volatility (Vincent et al., 2019)", indicating pupil dilation is used to gauge certainty/volatility.

Citing Palmer et al. (2019), the article states that sensorimotor beta power "reflects the precision-weighting afforded to sensory prediction errors," making beta-band EEG a measurement of that construct.
